div1.p: Havard provides evidence that Caldas' and Bellingaghi's theories are unsound and should not be accepted. He includes a detailed time-line of events and a list of arguments to conclude his report against Caldas. Enclosed are charts, reports, and other documents used as evidence. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

HEADQUARTERS
DEPARTMENT OF CUBA
OFFICE OF CHIEF SURGEON,
HAVANA.

PROCEEDINGS OF A MEDICAL COMMISSION APPOINTED
BY THE FOLLOWING CIRCULAR LETTER.

Circular Letter, )
(
No. 59. )

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA,
Havana, August 7, 1901.
A medical commission, to consist of:

Major Valery Havard, Surgeon, U.S. Army, Chief Surgeon of the
Department;

The Physicians composing the Havana Yellow Fever Board;
will meet at Las Animas Hospital in this city at 4 o'clock P.M.,
August 9, 1901, or as soon thereafter as practicable, for the pur-
pose of examining into the propositions and claims of Drs. Caldas
and Bellinzaghi, and submit, in connection therewith, such recom-
mendations as it may deem best for the interest of science and
medicine.
BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL WOOD:

H. L. SCOTT,
Captain 7th Cavalry,
Adjutant General.

In compliance with the above letter, the commission met at
Las Animas Hospital on August 9th at 4 P.M.; all the members
present; Drs. Caldas and Bellinzaghi also present.

Dr. Caldas stated to the commission that he had discovered
the pathogenic microbe of yellow fever and, from cultures there-
of, prepared a curative serum and prophylactic vaccine; that he
was convinced of the efficacy of his vaccine and desired to be
(2)
furnished the opportunity of demonstrating this efficacy before
the commission. He proposed that a certain number of non-
immune persons be inoculated with his vaccine and when thus
immunized against yellow fever that they should be bitten with
infected mosquitoes; this he declared could be done with perfect
impunity as it was impossible for persons immunized with his
vaccine to contract yellow fever. He then described the pro-
cess by which he immunizes the horse and obtains his curative
serum, and the process by which he prepares his prophylactic
vaccine, which is an attenuated culture of his microbe. He also
explained his procedure to produce immunization in man; as his
vaccine is liable to develop marked febrile movement and other
yellow fever symptoms he previously injects a dose of his serum
to ward off such symptoms. The commission then requested that
he would demonstrate his pathogenic microbe and describe the
method of its isolation and culture; this he formally declined
to do, because of his pledge to the company organized to exploit
his discovery, and also because he thought such demonstration
would, at this time, result in nothing but useless scientific
wrangles. This much, however, he was willing to divulge, namely,
that his microbe is not found in the blood but always in the
intestines, having been present in every case examined. If per-
mitted, said he, to vaccinate non-immune persons, and these are
subjected to the bite of infected mosquitoes and do not develop
yellow fever, the causative relation of his microbe to the dis-
ease would be indirectly proved.

Having been asked by what tests he had convinced himself
of the efficacy of his vaccine, he stated that, during the past
two years, he had inoculated with it 23 young men, mostly students,
at Rio Grande do Sul, where yellow fever is unknown, previous to
their going to Rio de Janeiro where yellow fever is endemic, and
that none of these young men had, so far as he knew, contracted
the fever. Upon the request of the commission, he submitted
that statement in writing, but without any other evidence or
proof than his own declaration. Referring to his curative
serum, he informed the commission that in Brazil, as well as in
Mexico, he and Dr. Bellinzaghi had obtained with it an average of
85 per cent. of cures, a result which, even if correctly reported,
did not appear to the commission sufficiently promising to jus-
tify experimentation with it in Havana.

After careful discussion of the subject, the commission
decided that, since Dr. Caldas did not intend to demonstrate his
microbe and thus put his claim upon a true scientific basis, it
should decline active cooperation in his tests; it, however,
recommended that the necessary facilities be afforded him, and
stood ready, in its official capacity, to watch results and report
upon them.

Thereupon, Dr. Bellinzaghi engaged four non-immune immigrants
and, as required by the commission, made with them a written con-
tract whereby they voluntarily offered themselves to be inocu-
lated with Dr. Caldas' vaccine and then bitten by infected mos-
quitoes, for a certain stipulated sum of money, to be paid on the
termination of the experiment. These four men were sent to
(4)
Las Animas Hospital and kept in a mosquito-proof, wire-screened
room.

August 14th. The commission met at 11.30 A.M. at Las
Animas Hospital. They found that two of the four men selected
by Dr. Caldas for his experiments were probably immunes. The
other two named respectively Antonio Gomez and Paulino Alonso
received each 12 c.c. of Dr. Caldas' serum, injected in the glute-
al region by Dr. Bellinzaghi.

August 15th. The commission met at 11 A.M. at Las Animas
Hospital. A very slight febrile reaction, and some local ten-
derness had followed the injection of the serum. The two sub-
jects were inoculated by Dr. Caldas, in the same region, with 3 c.
c. of the vaccine obtained by Dr. Caldas from an attenuated and
filtered culture of his bacillus. He explained that this vac-
cine produces a very sharp reaction if it be not preceded by an
injection of the antitoxic serum. The accompanying chart of
Paulino Alonso shows that the so-called vaccine was followed by
a slight reaction. Dr. Caldas declared that his subject would
be immunized in five days. The commission decided that the
infected mosquitoes should be applied one week after the vac-
cination.

August 22nd. At 9.30 A.M. the commission met at the of-
fice of the Chief Surgeon, Drs. Caldas and Bellinzaghi being
present. It was resolved that the commission meet in the af-
ternoon at Las Animas Hospital, and apply two infected mosquitoes
to one of the subjects previously vaccinated by Drs. Caldas and
Bellinzaghi; the other subject to remain under observation, and
to be inoculated later if the first should appear to be protect-
(5)
ed by the supposed immunizing vaccine. The Brazilian gentlemen
were warned that the experiment was a dangerous one; that the
yellow fever that was being produced by the mosquitoes then a-
vailable was of a grave type. They were further told that the
experiment should not be performed without stating clearly to
the subjects the probable dangers. The Brazilian gentlemen
expressed themselves as absolutely certain that the subjects
had been absolutely immunized against yellow fever by the vac-
cine.

The commission met at 4 P.M. in the Inoculation Station of
Las Animas Hospital, Drs. Caldas and Bellinzaghi being present.
After the subject had been told the nature of the experiments,
and the risk incurred, he, of his own free will subjected himself
to the experiment. Two mosquitoes were then applied to his
arm. One of the insects applied had previously produced a mild
attack of yellow fever, and the other, when first applied with
three other insects, had produced a mild case, and when applied
the second time had produced, in conjunction with one other in-
sect, a severe (subsequently fatal) case. The subject and his
companion, who had also been vaccinated, but not bitten by in-
fected mosquitoes, were then transferred to Hospital No. 1, and
placed together in one of the wire-screened rooms in the wards
of Dr. Agramonte. Drs. Caldas and Bellinzaghi were allowed free
access to the ward.

August 24th. Drs. Finlay and Guiteras visited the subject
at Hospital No. 1 and found him well.

August 25th. Dr. Albertini visited the patient at 4 P.M.
and found that his temperature had risen a few tenths of a
degree above the normal. The face and conjunctivae were slight-
ly injected. The gums were red. The patient did not complain
of any symptoms.

August 26th. At 9 A.M. the commission met at Hospital
No. 1 to examine the case of Paulino Alonso, the subject who had
been bitten by the infected mosquitoes. Drs. Caldas and Bellin-
zaghi were present. The patient was found to have a tempera-
ture of 39.8 and pulse 90. The invasion had commenced the
preceding afternoon, exactly three days after the bite of the
infected mosquitoes. The patient complained of some headache
and backache. The headache was frontal. The face and con-
junctivae were decidedly injected. There was some photofobia.
The chest and arms also presented considerable peripheral hyper-
aemia. The liver and spleen were not enlarged. There was no
albumen in the urine. Dr. Caldas at once opined that the case
could not be one of yellow fever, because there was no intense
supraorbital pain and rachialgia, no albumen in the urine and no
enlargement of the liver. The commission, differing with Dr.
Caldas as to the presence or absence of some of the symptoms
mentioned, and as to the importance of others, were of opinion
that the symptoms present were those of yellow fever in the
first day of the disease, but they concluded that a final diag-
nosis should not be made until the disease was more fully de-
veloped. See the temperature chart.

August 27th. The commission met at Hospital No. 1, Dr.
Bellinzaghi being present. The temperature of the patient was
39.6, and the pulse 92. A distinct trace of albumen had appear-
ed in the urine. The fever was a continued fever. An exam-
ination of the blood had shown the absence of malarial para-
sites. The patient was nauseated. On the previous day there
had been a fall of the pulse corresponding with a rise of the
temperature. See temperature chart. Other symptoms had be-
come intensified. The commission, therefore, gave their opinion
to the effect that the case was one of yellow fever.

August 28th. The commission met at Hospital No. 1 at 9.30
A.M. The patient had vomited several times since the last
visit. He had passed black fecal matter. The gums were
spongy. There was slight icterus. The commission resolved
to meet at the office of the Chief Surgeon, Col. Havard, to hear
the views of Dr. Caldas.

August 28th. At 4 P.M. the commission met in the office
of the Chief Surgeon, Drs. Caldas and Bellinzaghi being present.
The Chairman, Col Havard asked the opinion of Dr. Caldas as to the
nature of the case infected by mosquitoes. Dr. Caldas was most
positive in his opinion that the case was not one of yellow
fever, - that he had none of the pathognomonic symptoms of the
disease. He was told that the opinion of all the physicians,
outside of the commission, who had examined the case was unani-
mous to the effect that the case was one of yellow fever. Dr.
Caldas was sure that the case was one of septicaemia, - a putrid
fever caused by infection from mosquito bites. His reasons for
(8)
rejecting the diagnosis of yellow fever were: that the patient had
had no initial chill, no supraorbital pain, no rachialgia, no
nausea, no epigastralgia, no enlargement of the liver, and no dis-
crepancy between the pulse and temperature. The commission
differed from Dr. Caldas as to the absence of some of these symp-
toms and as to the importance of others. Dr. Caldas was told
that the patient had been vomiting since the previous evening,
and a specimen of the last vomit, just before the meeting, was
shown him. The vomit presented a dirty greenish color, and a
deposit of dark red floculi. In the opinion of the commission
this was the first stage of the black vomit of yellow fever.
Dr. Caldas, however, appeared to attach no importance to the mat-
ter. He seemed not to care to look at the specimen until he
was made to do so. He was then shown the temperature chart,
and his attention was called to the fall of the pulse corres-
ponding with a rise of the temperature. It was very evident
that Dr. Caldas had not followed carefully the course of the
temperature during his visits to the hospital. The commission
received the impression that Dr. Caldas had made up his mind to
the effect that the case should not be one of yellow fever, and
he would not study it with a scientific spirit. He was asked,
however, to present, in writing, his reasons for not accepting
the diagnosis of yellow fever. His statement accompanies this
report.

In the opinion of the commission the vaccine prepared by
Dr. Caldas had failed to immunize against yellow fever; and it
was therefore decided to discontinue all experiments with the
(9)
serum and vaccine prepared by Drs. Caldas and Bellinzaghi. It
was also decided that other physicians should be invited to
visit the patient.

August 29th. The visiting and resident staff of Hospital
No. 1 including Drs. Diago, Duenas, Jacobsen, and others, and also
Professor Castro, and Drs. Cabrera and Valdes, experienced physi-
cians of Havana have examined the patient and confirmed the
diagnosis of yellow fever. The temperature has fallen below
the normal. The pulse is 80 and soft. There is some general
icteric discoloration. The urine contains a very large quan-
tity of albumen.

August 30th. The temperature rose yesterday for a few
hours above the normal to fall again to-day. The urine con-
tains about two grams of albumen.

September 3rd. The commission met at the office of the
Chief Surgeon. A communication from Dr. Caldas defending his
position that the case of Paulino Alonso was one of putrid
fever produced by the bite of mosquitoes was read. The commis-
sion did not deem it necessary to further discuss this communi-
cation because they have already embodied in this report their
reasons for the diagnosis of yellow fever.
In conclusion the commission would state

1st. That Dr. Caldas has kept his alleged discoveries from
the study of other scientists;

2nd. That the claim made by Dr. Caldas that the pathogenic
agent of yellow fever is found only in the intestinal tract is
(10)
in direct opposition to the evidence furnished by the mosquito
inoculations and the direct blood inoculations made by the Board
presided over by Major Walter Reed, U.S.A. and other experimen-
tors.

3rd. That the attempt made by Dr. Caldas to immunize an
individual against yellow fever, by means of a vaccine prepared
by him, has failed.

The commission therefore recommends that all further exper-
iments with the vaccine and the curative serum of Dr. Caldas
should be discontinued.

There being no further business before it the commission
adjourned sine die.

V. Havard
Major & Surgeon, U.S. Army
Chief Surgeon

Juan Guiteras
Carlos Finlay

AD Albertini
W. C. Gorgas.
Major & Surg. U.S.A.

Four
